objectives: Learn names for common foods we eat, animals we see, and clothes we wear.
Use these new words to talk about our daily life.
Understand the difference between farm animals and wild animals.

sections.text: These are words for different kinds of food we eat, their taste, and how we describe them. Food gives us energy to live, work, and play.

examples.label: Rice
examples.value: Small, white or brown grains that we cook and eat as a main food.

examples.label: Wheat
examples.value: A grain used to make flour for roti, chapati, or bread.

examples.label: Dal (Pulses)
examples.value: Dried lentils or peas that we cook to make a thick soup or curry.

examples.label: Roti / Chapati
examples.value: A flat, round bread made from wheat flour, cooked on a pan.

examples.label: Bread
examples.value: A food made from flour, water, and yeast, baked in an oven.

examples.label: Vegetable
examples.value: A plant or part of a plant used as food, such as potato, onion, or carrot.

examples.label: Fruit
examples.value: The sweet, fleshy part of a tree or plant that can be eaten as food.

examples.label: Mango
examples.value: A sweet, juicy fruit that is known as the 'king of fruits'.

examples.label: Banana
examples.value: A long, yellow, sweet fruit that is easy to peel and eat.

examples.label: Apple
examples.value: A round, sweet fruit, usually red or green, with white flesh.

examples.label: Orange
examples.value: A round, juicy citrus fruit with a tough, orange-colored skin.

examples.label: Milk
examples.value: A white liquid produced by cows and other mammals, which we drink.

examples.label: Water
examples.value: A clear liquid, without color or taste, that we need to drink to live.

examples.label: Tea
examples.value: A hot drink made by pouring boiling water onto dried leaves.

examples.label: Sugar
examples.value: A sweet substance, usually in the form of white or brown crystals, used to sweeten food and drinks.

examples.label: Salt
examples.value: A white substance used to add flavor to food.

examples.label: Spice
examples.value: A substance like chili, turmeric, or cumin used to add flavor and aroma to food.

examples.label: Oil
examples.value: A fatty liquid used for cooking and frying.

examples.label: Sweet
examples.value: Having the taste of sugar or honey.

examples.label: Sour
examples.value: Having a sharp taste like a lemon.

examples.label: Salty
examples.value: Tasting of salt.

examples.label: Spicy
examples.value: Having a strong, hot flavor from spices.

examples.label: Fresh
examples.value: Food that is newly made or collected, not old.

examples.label: Stale
examples.value: Food that is no longer fresh and good to eat.

examples.label: Hot
examples.value: Food that has a high temperature.

examples.label: Cold
examples.value: Food that has a low temperature.

examples.label: Curry
examples.value: A dish of meat or vegetables cooked in a spicy sauce.

examples.label: Salad
examples.value: A mixture of raw vegetables such as lettuce, tomato, and cucumber.

examples.label: Snack
examples.value: A small amount of food eaten between main meals.

examples.label: Meal
examples.value: An occasion when food is eaten, such as breakfast, lunch, or dinner.

usage_examples: My mother cooks rice and dal for lunch.
The farmer grows wheat in his field.
Roti is a common part of our daily meal.
We must eat fresh fruits and vegetables every day.
The mango is a very sweet fruit.
I drink a glass of milk in the morning.
Always drink clean water.
My father likes to drink tea after his meal.
Don't put too much salt in the curry.
Indian food is known for its spices.
This sweet dish is very tasty.
The lemon juice is very sour.
The curry is too spicy for me.
Be careful, the soup is very hot.
We had a heavy meal at the festival.

sections.text: These are words for animals we see on farms, in our homes, and in the wild. We also learn words to describe them.

examples.label: Cow
examples.value: A large farm animal that gives us milk.

examples.label: Buffalo
examples.value: A large, dark farm animal that gives milk and is used for work.

examples.label: Goat
examples.value: A small farm animal that gives milk and meat.

examples.label: Sheep
examples.value: A farm animal with a thick woolly coat, kept for its wool and meat.

examples.label: Horse
examples.value: A large animal with a long mane and tail, used for riding and pulling carts.

examples.label: Donkey
examples.value: An animal like a small horse with long ears, used for carrying loads.

examples.label: Chicken
examples.value: A farm bird raised for its meat and eggs.

examples.label: Dog
examples.value: A common pet animal known for being loyal and guarding homes.

examples.label: Cat
examples.value: A small, furry animal often kept as a pet, known for catching mice.

examples.label: Tiger
examples.value: A large, powerful wild cat with black stripes on orange fur.

examples.label: Lion
examples.value: A large, wild cat from Africa and India, known as the 'king of the jungle'.

examples.label: Elephant
examples.value: The largest land animal, with a long trunk and big ears.

examples.label: Deer
examples.value: A graceful wild animal that eats grass. Male deer have antlers.

examples.label: Monkey
examples.value: A clever animal that lives in trees and loves to jump.

examples.label: Snake
examples.value: A long, thin reptile with no legs.

examples.label: Crow
examples.value: A large, black bird with a loud, harsh call.

examples.label: Parrot
examples.value: A colorful bird that can be taught to copy human speech.

examples.label: Ant
examples.value: A very small insect that lives in large groups.

examples.label: Butterfly
examples.value: An insect with large, often colorful wings.

examples.label: Domestic
examples.value: An animal that is tamed and kept by humans, like farm animals.

examples.label: Wild
examples.value: An animal that lives in nature and is not tamed.

examples.label: Big
examples.value: Large in size.

examples.label: Small
examples.value: Little in size.

examples.label: Fast
examples.value: Moving at a high speed.

examples.label: Slow
examples.value: Moving at a low speed.

examples.label: Loud
examples.value: Making a lot of noise.

examples.label: Quiet
examples.value: Making very little or no noise.

examples.label: Tail
examples.value: The part of an animal's body that sticks out from its rear end.

examples.label: Wings
examples.value: The parts of a bird or insect's body that it uses for flying.

examples.label: Fur
examples.value: The thick hair that covers the bodies of many animals like cats and dogs.

usage_examples: The cow is a domestic animal.
The farmer uses a donkey to carry sacks of grain.
The tiger is a wild animal.
We saw a deer in the forest.
A parrot can talk like humans.
The butterfly has beautiful wings.
An elephant is a very big animal.
An ant is a very small insect.
A cheetah is a very fast runner.
A tortoise moves very slow.
The lion's roar is very loud.
The cat is very quiet when it hunts.
The dog is wagging its tail.
The cat has soft, white fur.

sections.text: These are words for the clothes we wear on different parts of our body, for different seasons, and to describe them.

examples.label: Shirt
examples.value: A piece of clothing for the upper body, with sleeves and a collar.

examples.label: T-shirt
examples.value: A simple, short-sleeved shirt with no collar.

examples.label: Kurta
examples.value: A loose, collarless shirt worn by men and women in India.

examples.label: Pants / Trousers
examples.value: A piece of clothing that covers both legs.

examples.label: Shorts
examples.value: Short pants that end above the knees.

examples.label: Dhoti
examples.value: A traditional lower garment worn by men in India.

examples.label: Skirt
examples.value: A piece of clothing for women and girls that hangs down from the waist.

examples.label: Sari
examples.value: A long piece of cloth worn by women in India.

examples.label: Sweater
examples.value: A warm piece of clothing, usually knitted, worn in winter.

examples.label: Jacket
examples.value: A piece of clothing with sleeves, worn over other clothes when it is cold.

examples.label: Raincoat
examples.value: A waterproof coat worn during the rainy season to stay dry.

examples.label: Shoes
examples.value: Footwear worn to protect our feet when we go outside.

examples.label: Socks
examples.value: A piece of clothing worn on the feet, inside shoes.

examples.label: Sandals / Chappals
examples.value: Open footwear with straps to hold them on the feet.

examples.label: Cap / Hat
examples.value: A covering for the head, worn for protection from the sun or cold.

examples.label: Belt
examples.value: A strip of leather or cloth worn around the waist to hold up pants.

examples.label: Scarf / Dupatta
examples.value: A long piece of cloth worn around the neck, head, or shoulders.

examples.label: Pocket
examples.value: A small bag sewn into or on clothing, used for carrying small items.

examples.label: Button
examples.value: A small, round object on a shirt or jacket used to fasten it.

examples.label: Zipper
examples.value: A device used to fasten clothes, consisting of two rows of teeth that are interlocked by a sliding tab.

examples.label: New
examples.value: Something that has not been worn before.

examples.label: Old
examples.value: Something that has been worn for a long time.

examples.label: Clean
examples.value: Clothing that is free from dirt.

examples.label: Dirty
examples.value: Clothing that is not clean.

examples.label: Loose
examples.value: Clothing that is not tight-fitting.

examples.label: Tight
examples.value: Clothing that fits the body closely.

examples.label: Colorful
examples.value: Having many bright colors.

examples.label: Plain
examples.value: Having only one color and no pattern.

examples.label: Cotton
examples.value: A type of fabric that is light and good for summer.

examples.label: Woolen
examples.value: Made of wool, from sheep, which is warm and good for winter.

usage_examples: I wear a clean shirt to school.
My father wears pants to work.
My mother wears a beautiful sari during festivals.
In winter, I wear a warm sweater.
Put on your raincoat, it's raining outside.
Always wear shoes when you go out.
My socks have a hole in them.
I wear a cap to protect my head from the sun.
I keep my money in my pocket.
One button of my shirt is missing.
I have a new dress for my birthday.
Your clothes are dirty, please change them.
I like to wear loose clothes in summer.
The child wore a colorful frock.
A woolen sweater keeps us warm.

subtopics.title: Actions with Food, Animals, and Clothes

sections.text: These are common actions (verbs) related to our food, the animals around us, and the clothes we wear.

examples.label: Eat
examples.value: To put food into your mouth and swallow it.

examples.label: Drink
examples.value: To take liquid into your mouth and swallow it.

examples.label: Cook
examples.value: To prepare food by using heat.

examples.label: Cut
examples.value: To divide something into pieces using a knife.

examples.label: Grow
examples.value: To cultivate plants or crops.

examples.label: Taste
examples.value: To notice the flavor of food or drink.

examples.label: Smell
examples.value: To notice the aroma of something with your nose.

examples.label: Run
examples.value: The action of animals like dogs and horses moving fast.

examples.label: Fly
examples.value: The action of birds and insects moving through the air.

examples.label: Swim
examples.value: The action of fish moving in water.

examples.label: Crawl
examples.value: The action of insects or snakes moving along the ground.

examples.label: Jump
examples.value: The action of monkeys or goats pushing off the ground.

examples.label: Bark
examples.value: The sound a dog makes.

examples.label: Roar
examples.value: The loud, deep sound a lion or tiger makes.

examples.label: Graze
examples.value: The action of cows or goats eating grass.

examples.label: Hunt
examples.value: The action of wild animals chasing and catching other animals for food.

examples.label: Wear
examples.value: To have clothes on your body.

examples.label: Wash
examples.value: To clean clothes with water and soap.

examples.label: Dry
examples.value: To make wet clothes free from water.

examples.label: Fold
examples.value: To bend a piece of clothing so that one part covers another.

examples.label: Mend / Sew
examples.value: To repair a hole or tear in clothes, usually with a needle and thread.

examples.label: Button
examples.value: To fasten a shirt or jacket using buttons.

examples.label: Zip
examples.value: To fasten a piece of clothing using a zipper.

examples.label: Polish
examples.value: To make shoes shiny by rubbing them with polish.

usage_examples: We should eat healthy food.
My mother cooks delicious meals for us.
Farmers grow rice and wheat in the fields.
The dog started to bark at the stranger.
Birds fly high in the sky.
The cows are grazing in the field.
The tiger hunts for its food at night.
I wear clean clothes to school.
My mother will wash the dirty clothes on Sunday.
Please fold your clothes neatly.
My grandmother can mend my torn shirt.
Don't forget to polish your school shoes.
